root: ^Fräulein Janice, wie geht's? Guessing by your appearance, fantastisch, no?
^Hi, Karl. It's not as bad as it looks. And how are you?
^So, I saw you dancing at the Übertanz Club the other day. You got some serious moves, girl.
^Do you feel like teaching me a little?
^Sure, Karl. But what will I get in return?
^I try to be nice and you keep asking for money.
^Why are you doing this with your singing ability?
^I could find you a better job.

rudeReply: ^Must you charge for every single thing?
^Fick dich, Karl! You're such a prick.
singToMe: ^Janice, I also know you have a beautiful voice. Why don't you come with me to a party tonight?
^I'll introduce you to a few influential people.
^Cabaret owners and such...They'll go mad over you.
^You might end up leaving the streets for good...
^Karl, you are such a smarmy fellow...
^But ok, pick me up at my place tonight. There's hardly any work these days, anyway.
^Please, get some sleep. Your voice needs to rest.
^Fine, I'll go. As soon as I finish the cigarette.
goodJob: ^Janice, why are you still doing this? You can find a better job!
^Says a drunk who lets other people sign his paintings.
^No, seriously. My old regiment is looking for new computers.
^I'm sure you're a lot better with math than I am.
^But of course. I used to be a champion of Weimar children's math competition.
^No, Karl. I dropped out of school when my mother died. I'm not here because I'm bored, you know.
^Well, they're pretty desperate. If I put in a good word for you, they just might hire you.
^Mein lieutenant couldn't add up double digit numbers. Trust me, compared to him, you are Einstein.
^Do you want the job or not?
^If it works out, you know where to find me.
^Very good. Now if you'll excuse me, I'm fashionably late for work.
^Don't get fired, please. I don't want to share the corner with you.
